description.en: The course offers an analytical overview of different actors and their policy practices pertaining to the overlapping and interlacing spheres of state and society in contemporary Russia. We shall discuss both formal (elite-based / governmental) and societal (informal / non-state-based) institutions, groups and organizations operating in Russia's public domains and interacting with each other to the point of indistinction. To trace these interactions, we shall apply different academic conceptualization of power (sovereign, institutional, communicative, epistemic, "pastoral"), and look at how they function in those realms of Russian domestic politics that affect the country's foreign policies. Of particular importance is to uncover the multiple facets of Russian illiberalism and relate them to the much discussed phenomenon of global conservatism. Within this general framework we shall also identify and unpack the sources of counter-hegemonic resistance spread all across the society and exemplified by practices of challenging and opposing the Kremlin rule.
description.et: Aine pakub analüütilist ülevaadet erinevatest osalejatest ja nende poliitilistest tavadest, mis on seotud riigi ja ühiskonna kattuvate ja põimuvate sfääridega tänapäeva Venemaal.

objectives.en: The main goal of the course is to two-pronged. First, it seeks to conceptualize different forms of power relations in Russia (sovereign, institutional, communicative, epistemic, 'pastoral'). Second, the course aims to discuss the roles of specific actors (civil society organizations, subnational authorities, opposition groups, etc.) within each of the forms of power mentioned above.
objectives.et: Aine põhieesmärk on püüa kontseptualiseerida erinevaid võimusuhete vorme Venemaal (suveräänne, institutsionaalne, kommunikatiivne, episteemiline, 'pastoraalne'). Samuti aine eesmärgiks on arutada konkreetsete osalejate (kodanikuühiskonna organisatsioonid, riiklikud omavalitsused, opositsioonirühmad jne) rollide üle kõigis eespool nimetatud võimuvormides.

learning_outcomes.en:
Students who have successfully passed the course:
-	Identify main actors in Russian social and political realms
-	Explicate their roles and means / resources of influencing the relations of power
-	Establish connections between different forms of power
-	Use the acquired knowledge for a better understanding of political process in Russia and its short- and medium-terms perspectives.
learning_outcomes.et:
Aine edukalt läbinu:
- identifitseerib Venemaa ühiskondliku ja poliitilise maastiku peamisi tegureid ja osalejaid, nende rolle ja vahendeid / ressursse võimusuhete mõjutamiseks 
- loob seoseid erinevate võimuvormide vahel 
- kasutab omandatud teadmisi Venemaa poliitiliste protsesside ning selle lühi- ja täispika perspektiivi paremaks mõistmiseks.

description.et:
RESEARCH PAPER should be based on the analysis of at least three academic articles and is assessed according to the following criteria:
A - the paper demonstrates student's perfect knowledge of the reading materials and the course content, excellent writing skills, and contains conclusions relevant for the course. The academic / political controversies are duly described and commented
B - the student is familiar with the recommended literature, is aware of key concepts discussed during the course, and showed her/his ability to highlight its key points without getting into details and making comparisons with other similar cases or texts;
C- the student can engage with most of the academic arguments, is capable of analytically approaching the discussed topics and properly comprehend the main ideas of the course
D - the student is only superficially aware of the main issues touched upon by the recommended authors and the course instructor, and lacks a clear vision of the problems discussed
E - the student only scarcely discusses the key concepts in the literature and is minimally prepared for giving his/her expert opinion on the subject
F - the submitted paper is vague in language, or simply reiterates the well known facts, or is politically biased (for example, gives preference to one of many discourses or arguments), or is detached from empirical facts, or fails to cover alternative viewpoints existing in the literature or in political narratives. The paper lacks a clear structure or a concluding argument that summarizes the research.

TEAM-BASED PRSENTATIONS
For this assignment students are required to work in small groups tasked with preparing for and participating in a team-based presentation. Preparatory in-group work implies literature review, data search and distribution of roles within the group.  Two options for team work are available - scenario planning and project management.

A - the form of the presentation is excellent; the depth of the analysis and the level of independent interpretation is remarkable; the treatment of the subject is innovative and logical; the presentation is a remarkable achievement on the whole.
B - the form of the presentation is excellent;; bold interpretation based on connections; the treatment of the subject as a whole is logical and smooth.
C - the form of the presentation is in compliance with the requirements and correct; the treatment of the subject is logical, but there are some weaknesses from the point of view of the whole. 
D - the form of the presentation is in compliance with the requirements and, in general, correct; the analysis and independent interpreting is understandable, but at times insecure; the coverage of the subject is logical and associated.
E - the form of he presentation is, in general, in compliance with the requirements and correct; the coverage of the subject is, in general, logical, but the connections are full of gaps.

description.et: This class opens the course with an overview of the state of affairs in the Russian Studies discipline. Students will be familiarized with key concepts of the course and its structure, as well as grading policy and assignments.

The class offers a discussion on a variety of academic concepts indispensable for analysis of today's Russian political agency and subjectivity. Particular attention will be given to critical theories and their unexplored potential in the field of new Russia Studies
This class introduces the concept of historical time - and hence temporality - into the analysis of Russian historical narratives, and explains core distinctions with memory politics in Europe
Guest speaker for a case study:  Aytaç Yürükçü, University of Eastern Finland

The class introduces the concept of performativity and its theoretical background, and discusses its applicability for studying Russia's dislocated identity, security posture and other key political categories
This class focuses on the concept of space - and therefore new spatialities - as essential characteristics of Putin's regime and its transgressive relations with neighbors
The class discusses the applicability of bodily and corporeal interpretations of Russian politics, including issues of life and death, disciplining power and medicalization of politics.
The class delves into the importance of Russia's strategic narratives as communication tools and as weaponized discourses aimed at specific policy audiences.
This class is devoted to visual analysis as a research method instrumental for studying Russian domestic and foreign policies
The class discusses how Russian language becomes a matter of political conflicts and contestation
The Case of Russian - Finnish trans-border relations
The class discusses Russia's war in Ukraine from the perspective of necropolitics and violence
